title: How I Built My Portfolio
excerpt: A step-by-step explanation of building my personal portfolio using HTML, CSS, and JSON-driven blog posts.
content:
How I Built My Personal Portfolio Website

Creating my personal portfolio was one of the most rewarding projects I have ever completed. It allowed me to combine my passion for technology, design and storytelling into one digital space that reflects who I am as a cybersecurity and cloud enthusiast.

I wanted my website to showcase not only my professional work but also my learning journey. From exploring web development to building cybersecurity skills through hand-on experience. I was going for a simple and manageable website.

Planning and Design

Before writing any code, I started with a simple plan of how my website will look like, the structure and pages. I focused on sections that tell my story clearly:

  • Home/Landing Page:
  • Resume/About Me: My background, certifications and career focus.
  • Projects: Hands-on cybersecurity and cloud labs.
  • Blog: Articles about my experiences, certifications and achievements.
  • Contact: To make it easy for professionals and recruiters to reach me.

For design, I chose a modern and professional color scheme with whites, blacks and blue highlights.Colors that convey clarity and trust. My goal was a responsive layout that feels simple yet elegant.

Development and Structure

I built the portfolio using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. I used JSON files to store and manage my blog posts, so I can easily update or add new content without editing the code directly.

Each blog post is stored as a separate JSON file and the blog page automatically loads them dynamically. This approach makes the website lightweight and easy to maintain.

Hosting and Deployment

After completing development, I hosted my portfolio on GitHub Pages, which provides free and reliable hosting for static sites. I did so by uploading it to a repository named <username>.github.io, which uses the same name as my GitHub username. This setup makes it easy to publish and update my site. Every time I make changes locally, I simply push new commits to GitHub. GitHub Actions then handles the entire CI/CD process by automatically testing, building and deploying my code.

Key Features

  • Dynamic blog posts powered by JSON files.
  • Responsive design that works on all devices.
  • Lightweight and fast - No heavy frameworks.
  • Simple content management - just edit or add a JSON file.

Lessons Learned

This project taught me how structure, usability and performance come together to create a meaningful user experience. I also strengthened my skills in:

  • DOM manipulation with JavaScript.
  • JSON-based content management.
  • Clean and modular web design.
  • Version control with Git and GitHub.

Whatâ€™s Next

Building this site inspired me to think bigger. I plan to expand it into a personal cybersecurity learning hub, where I will share my CTF write-ups, security labs and certification insights. Growth happens step by step.
